head.title: Fame Eludes Him, But Why Is That?

hedline.hl1: Fame Eludes Him, But Why Is That?

abstract.p: Ben Ratliff reviews concert by tenor saxophonist Teddy Edwards at Jazz Standard (S)

block.p: Teddy Edwards, the West Coast tenor saxophonist now in his mid-70's, has a reputation as one of jazz's unsolved mysteries, someone who should have been famous but isn't. Teddy Edwards, the West Coast tenor saxophonist now in his mid-70's, has a reputation as one of jazz's unsolved mysteries, someone who should have been famous but isn't. You wouldn't know it from his presence: he's a warm, generous performer who wears light-colored suits and likes to see if the audience is following his jokes. On Wednesday he gave a charming, low-stress performance with a pickup band.

It was the type of loose show that made you stretch your hearing a little to get to the heart of why Mr. Edwards is such a good player, but all was revealed in time. Mr. Edwards was one of the first bebop tenor saxophonists in the mid-1940's, but his career leveled out early because of a lack of opportunities in Los Angeles after the decline of the Central Avenue scene and some health problems. Despite the associations of bebop with speed, he doesn't hustle.
Most of all he's a great blues player: when the fast, fractured lines of bebop momentarily emerged here and there, you could see how they were part of a continuum with rhythm-and-blues.

He split the ballad ''Tenderly'' into two sections: he warmed it up playing only with the pianist, John Hicks, and in few introductory choruses he was a freehand, laid-back player, walking calmly through his improvisations, working in long tones and long, arpeggiated stretches. After the rhythm section kicked in, there was a release of tension, and Mr. Edwards started to work on larger, more continuous ideas, as if he were preaching through the horn.

The bassist Paul Nowinsky and the drummer Alvester Garnett picked up Mr. Edwards's growing conviction; the snare-drum beats acquired a dramatic snap, and all of a sudden, the music acquired direction.
